title: Customize Your iPhone with Unique App Launch Sound Effects
description: There are plenty of ways to personalize your iPhone or iPad, right down to how it responds when you open an app. With a quick setup, you can have it play a custom sound every time you launch your favorite apps, adding a unique touch to your daily routine. Apple's Shortcuts app makes it easy to automate tasks, including playing a custom sound whenever you launch an app. Whether you want a nostalgic startup chime, a sci-fi beep, or a voice clip announcing each app, this feature adds a unique touch to your iPhone or iPad experience. Once set up, your iPhone or iPad will automatically play the assigned sound every time you open the selected app — no extra taps required. RequirementsiPhone or iPad running the latest iOS or iPadOS version Shortcuts app (preinstalled) A sound effect (either a system-based one or a custom file) Start a new personal 'App' automationLaunch the Shortcuts app on your iPhone or iPad. text: There are plenty of ways to personalize your iPhone or iPad, right down to how it responds when you open an app. With a quick setup, you can have it play a custom sound every time you launch your favorite apps, adding a unique touch to your daily routine.Apple's Shortcuts app makes it easy to automate tasks, including playing a custom sound whenever you launch an app. Whether you want a nostalgic startup chime, a sci-fi beep, or a voice clip announcing each app, this feature adds a unique touch to your iPhone or iPad experience. Once set up, your iPhone or iPad will automatically play the assigned sound every time you open the selected app — no extra taps required.RequirementsiPhone or iPad running the latest iOS or iPadOS versionShortcuts app (preinstalled)A sound effect (either a system-based one or a custom file) Start a new personal 'App' automationLaunch the Shortcuts app on your iPhone or iPad. This is where you'll create an automation that plays a sound whenever you open a specific app or group of apps. Open the Automation tab (on iPad, it's in the sidebar), then either tap the plus (+) icon or the New Automation button. From the list of personal automation options, select App. This trigger ensures the automation runs when you open a specific app. Choose your app (or apps)Tap Choose next to App to see a list of all your iPhone or iPad apps. You can choose one or multiple apps on the Choose App list. For example, if you'd like a money-like sound to play whenever you open any payment-related apps, such as Apple Wallet, Coinbase Wallet, and Venmo, ensure all those apps are checked in the list. Hit Done when finished, then verify that Is Opened is checked for the automation, which should be the default option. Change to 'Run Immediately' to avoid promptsUnder Is Opened, change Run After Confirmation to Run Immediately so Shortcuts does not ask you to play the sound every time the automation is triggered. Also, verify that Notify When Run is disabled, which would be another thing that would kill the mood of the sound effect. Then, hit Next to continue. Choose your sound's sourceOn the shortcut selection screen that appears, choose New Blank Automation. Then, decide what sound you want to use. If it's a system sound, you can use the URL action. If it's a system sound, you can use the URL action. If it's a sound file stored in the Files app or a connected cloud service like Dropbox, select the File action instead. Use a text tone or system soundSearch for and add the URL action to the new shortcut. This passes the specified URL to the next action. In this case, the URL will be a local system file on your iPhone or iPad. These include text tones, UI sounds, and other audio effects in either .caf or .m4r format. Unfortunately, ringtones are stored in a restricted directory, so Shortcuts cannot access them.I've added a list of sound files with their file paths at the end of this article; just choose one, copy its location, and paste it into the URL action box where "apple.com" is shown. I am using the Payment Success sound for Wallet apps.file:///System/Library/Audio/UISounds/payment_success.cafThen, move to Step 5 to add the next action. Use a custom sound fileSearch for and add the File action to the new shortcut. This passes the specified file as output. In this case, the file will be found in the Files app on your iPhone or iPad. I won't go over creating your own ringtones or text tones to use, but you can do that if you want — just make sure you store the files on iCloud Drive, One My iPhone or On My iPad, or a compatible third-party cloud service. The same goes for finding and saving a sound file from online somewhere — make sure you store it where it can be accessed in Files. Most audio file formats will work (.caf, .m4a, .m4r, .mp3, etc.).Tap File to choose your music or sound effect in the File action box.Then, browse for and select the audio file wherever you stored it. The file path will appear in the File action box. Now, move to Step 5 to add the next action. Add the 'Play Sound' actionWhether you choose a system audio file or a custom one found in the Files app, the next part of the shortcut is the same — search for and add the Play Sound action. This plays the audio file passed as input. If the file you chose is unavailable or cannot be located, it will play the default notification sound instead.If you are using the Files action, adding Play Sound should automatically connect itself to it so that it will fetch and play the designated audio file. But if you are using the URL action, it might not. To set it, tap the > button in the Play Sound action box to expand the options. Then, tap Choose Variable and pick URL. Save the automationIf you want to make sure the right sound plays, you can hit the Play button to test out the shortcut. When ready, tap Done to save the automation. And now you're all set! Enjoy your new app launch sound effectsNow, whenever you open one of the selected apps assigned to the automation, your iPhone or iPad will automatically play your chosen sound effect. This simple automation adds a layer of personality to your iPhone or iPad, making everyday app launches more enjoyable. Whether for fun or accessibility, custom app sounds make your device truly yours. Local file names and pathsIf you want to use a sound already on your iPhone or iPad with the File action in Shortcuts, use one of the following. Note that these files were found on an iPhone 16 model running iOS 18, so some of them may not be available on other models. Charging Sound or Song for Your iPhone Whenever You Connect or Disconnect from PowerCover photo and screenshots by Gadget Hacks.
html:
There are plenty of ways to personalize your iPhone or iPad, right down to how it responds when you open an app. With a quick setup, you can have it play a custom sound every time you launch your favorite apps, adding a unique touch to your daily routine.

Apple's Shortcuts app makes it easy to automate tasks, including playing a custom sound whenever you launch an app. Whether you want a nostalgic startup chime, a sci-fi beep, or a voice clip announcing each app, this feature adds a unique touch to your iPhone or iPad experience. Once set up, your iPhone or iPad will automatically play the assigned sound every time you open the selected app — no extra taps required.

Requirements

  • iPhone or iPad running the latest iOS or iPadOS version

  • Shortcuts app (preinstalled)

  • A sound effect (either a system-based one or a custom file)

Start a new personal 'App' automation

Launch the Shortcuts app on your iPhone or iPad. This is where you'll create an automation that plays a sound whenever you open a specific app or group of apps. Open the Automation tab (on iPad, it's in the sidebar), then either tap the plus (+) icon or the New Automation button. From the list of personal automation options, select App. This trigger ensures the automation runs when you open a specific app.

Choose your app (or apps)

Tap Choose next to App to see a list of all your iPhone or iPad apps. You can choose one or multiple apps on the Choose App list. For example, if you'd like a money-like sound to play whenever you open any payment-related apps, such as Apple Wallet, Coinbase Wallet, and Venmo, ensure all those apps are checked in the list. Hit Done when finished, then verify that Is Opened is checked for the automation, which should be the default option.

Change to 'Run Immediately' to avoid prompts

Under Is Opened, change Run After Confirmation to Run Immediately so Shortcuts does not ask you to play the sound every time the automation is triggered. Also, verify that Notify When Run is disabled, which would be another thing that would kill the mood of the sound effect. Then, hit Next to continue.

Choose your sound's source

On the shortcut selection screen that appears, choose New Blank Automation. Then, decide what sound you want to use. If it's a system sound, you can use the URL action. If it's a system sound, you can use the URL action. If it's a sound file stored in the Files app or a connected cloud service like Dropbox, select the File action instead.

Use a text tone or system sound

Search for and add the URL action to the new shortcut. This passes the specified URL to the next action. In this case, the URL will be a local system file on your iPhone or iPad. These include text tones, UI sounds, and other audio effects in either .caf or .m4r format. Unfortunately, ringtones are stored in a restricted directory, so Shortcuts cannot access them.

I've added a list of sound files with their file paths at the end of this article; just choose one, copy its location, and paste it into the URL action box where "apple.com" is shown. I am using the Payment Success sound for Wallet apps.

file:///System/Library/Audio/UISounds/payment_success.caf

Then, move to Step 5 to add the next action.

Use a custom sound file

Search for and add the File action to the new shortcut. This passes the specified file as output. In this case, the file will be found in the Files app on your iPhone or iPad. I won't go over creating your own ringtones or text tones to use, but you can do that if you want — just make sure you store the files on iCloud Drive, One My iPhone or On My iPad, or a compatible third-party cloud service. The same goes for finding and saving a sound file from online somewhere — make sure you store it where it can be accessed in Files. Most audio file formats will work (.caf, .m4a, .m4r, .mp3, etc.).

Tap File to choose your music or sound effect in the File action box.

Then, browse for and select the audio file wherever you stored it. The file path will appear in the File action box. Now, move to Step 5 to add the next action.

Add the 'Play Sound' action

Whether you choose a system audio file or a custom one found in the Files app, the next part of the shortcut is the same — search for and add the Play Sound action. This plays the audio file passed as input. If the file you chose is unavailable or cannot be located, it will play the default notification sound instead.

If you are using the Files action, adding Play Sound should automatically connect itself to it so that it will fetch and play the designated audio file. But if you are using the URL action, it might not. To set it, tap the > button in the Play Sound action box to expand the options. Then, tap Choose Variable and pick URL.

Save the automation

If you want to make sure the right sound plays, you can hit the Play button to test out the shortcut. When ready, tap Done to save the automation. And now you're all set!

Enjoy your new app launch sound effects

Now, whenever you open one of the selected apps assigned to the automation, your iPhone or iPad will automatically play your chosen sound effect. This simple automation adds a layer of personality to your iPhone or iPad, making everyday app launches more enjoyable. Whether for fun or accessibility, custom app sounds make your device truly yours.

Local file names and paths

If you want to use a sound already on your iPhone or iPad with the File action in Shortcuts, use one of the following. Note that these files were found on an iPhone 16 model running iOS 18, so some of them may not be available on other models.

Text tones
